content.title: Keynesian Economics
content.definition: Keynesian economics is a macroeconomic theory developed by John Maynard Keynes that emphasizes the role of aggregate demand in determining economic output and employment, particularly in the short run. It argues that private sector decisions sometimes lead to inefficient macroeconomic outcomes (recessions, unemployment) and advocates active government intervention through fiscal policy (government spending and taxation) and monetary policy to stabilize the business cycle. The theory challenges classical economics' assumption that markets always self-correct to full employment.

definitions_glossary.keynesian_economics: Macroeconomic theory emphasizing demand-side factors and government intervention to stabilize economies - founded by Keynes (1936)
definitions_glossary.effective_demand: The total demand for goods and services that is backed by purchasing power and translates into actual purchases - Keynes's central concept
definitions_glossary.aggregate_demand: Total spending in the economy: AD = C + I + G + (X - M) - the primary determinant of output in Keynesian theory
definitions_glossary.consumption_function: C = C₀ + MPC × Yᵈ - relates consumption spending to disposable income, with autonomous component C₀
definitions_glossary.marginal_propensity_to_consume: MPC = ΔC/ΔYᵈ - the fraction of additional income that is spent rather than saved (typically 0.6-0.9)
definitions_glossary.liquidity_preference: Keynes's theory of money demand - people prefer liquid assets for transactions, precautionary, and speculative motives
definitions_glossary.liquidity_trap: When interest rates are so low that monetary policy becomes ineffective - additional money is hoarded rather than spent or lent
definitions_glossary.sticky_wages: Wages that resist downward adjustment due to contracts, norms, or efficiency wage concerns - prevents labor market clearing
definitions_glossary.animal_spirits: Keynes's term for the psychological factors (optimism, pessimism, confidence) driving investment decisions beyond rational calculation
definitions_glossary.paradox_of_thrift: If everyone tries to save more during recession, total spending falls, income falls, and total saving may actually decrease
definitions_glossary.fiscal_multiplier: The ratio of change in GDP to initial change in government spending or taxes - key mechanism for fiscal policy
definitions_glossary.automatic_stabilizers: Government policies that automatically increase spending or reduce taxes during recessions (unemployment insurance, progressive taxes)
definitions_glossary.crowding_out: When government spending displaces private investment by raising interest rates - limits fiscal policy effectiveness

key_points: Aggregate demand determines output and employment in the short run - 'demand creates its own supply' (reversing Say's Law)
Wages and prices are sticky downward - markets don't automatically clear, prolonged unemployment is possible
Investment is volatile due to 'animal spirits' - business confidence and expectations cause business cycle fluctuations
Consumption function: C = C₀ + MPC × Yᵈ, where MPC is the marginal propensity to consume (fraction of additional income spent)
Fiscal multiplier: Initial government spending creates income that generates further spending - multiplier = 1/(1-MPC)
Monetary policy works through interest rates affecting investment, but may become ineffective at zero lower bound (liquidity trap)
Fiscal policy (government spending, taxes) can directly stimulate aggregate demand during recessions
Paradox of thrift: Individual rationality (saving more in uncertainty) leads to collective irrationality (deeper recession)
Counter-cyclical policy: Governments should run deficits during recessions and surpluses during booms to stabilize economy
Keynesian economics dominated 1940s-1970s, challenged by stagflation, evolved into New Keynesian synthesis

examples.title: Great Depression (1929-1939) - Keynesian Analysis
examples.description: The depression that inspired Keynes's General Theory. Classical theory predicted self-correction, but unemployment remained at 25%+ for years. Keynesian explanation: collapse of aggregate demand (consumption, investment) not offset by wage/price flexibility. Investment fell due to pessimistic 'animal spirits' after 1929 crash. Solution: government spending to fill demand gap. New Deal programs provided partial stimulus, but full recovery required WWII military spending - massive fiscal expansion that proved Keynesian point.
examples.context: The motivating crisis for Keynesian theory - prolonged disequilibrium
examples.data: US unemployment: 25% (1933), still 14.6% in 1940. Real GDP fell 27% from 1929-1933. WWII spending was 40% of GDP (NBER data)

examples.title: 2008-2009 Financial Crisis Response
examples.description: Housing bubble collapse triggered financial crisis. Private spending collapsed - households deleveraged, businesses cut investment. Federal Reserve cut interest rates to near-zero (conventional monetary policy exhausted). Congress passed $787 billion American Recovery and Reinvestment Act (2009) - direct fiscal stimulus. Estimated multiplier of 1.5-2.0 on government purchases. GDP recovered faster than Eurozone, which pursued austerity. Demonstrated relevance of Keynesian prescriptions.
examples.context: Modern Keynesian fiscal stimulus in practice
examples.data: US fiscal stimulus: $787B (5.5% of GDP). Unemployment peak: 10% (2009). Recovery faster than EU (Blinder & Zandi, 2010)

examples.title: Japan's Lost Decade(s) - Liquidity Trap Example
examples.description: After 1991 asset bubble burst, Bank of Japan cut rates to near-zero. Despite abundant liquidity, investment remained weak due to pessimistic expectations and balance sheet problems. Classic liquidity trap: monetary policy pushing on a string. Keynesian prescription: fiscal stimulus. Japan implemented repeated fiscal packages but also raised consumption tax (1997), undermining stimulus. Illustrates both liquidity trap concept and importance of sustained fiscal effort.
examples.context: Liquidity trap limiting monetary policy effectiveness
examples.data: Japan interest rates near 0% since 1999. Nominal GDP in 2020 same as 1995. Debt/GDP: 260% (highest developed nation)

examples.title: 2020 COVID-19 Response - CARES Act
examples.description: Pandemic caused demand collapse (lockdowns, fear) and supply disruption. Congress passed $2.2 trillion CARES Act - direct payments, enhanced unemployment, PPP loans. Keynesian logic: replace lost private income/spending with government transfers. Consumption supported - personal saving rate spiked (transfers exceeded spending cuts) then fell as economy reopened. Debate: stimulus too large, contributing to 2021-22 inflation? Or prevented deeper depression?
examples.context: Largest peacetime fiscal stimulus in US history
examples.data: CARES Act: $2.2T (10% of GDP). Personal saving rate: 33% (April 2020). GDP: -3.4% (2020) then +5.7% (2021)

examples.title: Keynesian vs Austerity - UK 2010-2015
examples.description: UK coalition government pursued fiscal austerity after 2010 - cutting spending to reduce deficits. Keynesian critique: premature austerity during fragile recovery would slow growth (negative multiplier). Result: UK recovery slower than US which maintained stimulus longer. GDP growth averaged 1.9% vs US 2.3%. 'Double-dip' recession nearly occurred. Debate continues: was austerity cause of weak growth, or were structural factors primary?
examples.data: UK GDP growth: 1.9% avg (2010-14), US: 2.3% avg. UK deficit reduction at expense of growth (Wren-Lewis, 2016)

content.statement: Keynesian economics provides the theoretical foundation for understanding how aggregate demand determines economic output and employment in the short run, and why government intervention through fiscal and monetary policy may be necessary to stabilize market economies and prevent or mitigate recessions.

explanation.intuition: Imagine an economy as a circular flow: businesses pay workers, workers buy from businesses. If something breaks this flow (a crash causes pessimism, a pandemic shuts businesses), spending falls. But unlike classical theory where lower prices/wages would restore balance, Keynes observed that wages are sticky (workers resist pay cuts) and falling prices create expectations of further declines (why buy today?). The economy can get stuck in a low-output trap. The solution: have government inject spending directly to restart the circular flow. When consumers won't spend and businesses won't invest, government becomes the 'spender of last resort.' This demand creates income, which creates more spending (multiplier effect), pulling the economy out of recession.
explanation.key_insight: The revolutionary insight of Keynesian economics is that market economies can fail to self-correct - there's no automatic mechanism ensuring full employment. In classical economics, flexible wages would cure unemployment (unemployed workers accept lower wages until all are hired). Keynes showed why this fails: (1) wages are sticky downward, (2) even if wages fell, this reduces spending which reduces labor demand, (3) expectations matter - pessimism is self-fulfilling. Therefore, the government has a legitimate and necessary role stabilizing the economy through counter-cyclical fiscal policy. During recessions: spend more, tax less. During booms: spend less, tax more. This activist role was controversial in 1936 but became mainstream after WWII.
explanation.technical_details: The simple Keynesian model: Y = C + I + G in closed economy. Consumption function: C = C₀ + MPC·(Y - T). Equilibrium: Y = C₀ + MPC·(Y - T) + I + G. Solving: Y = [1/(1-MPC)]·[C₀ - MPC·T + I + G]. Government spending multiplier: ΔY/ΔG = 1/(1-MPC). Tax multiplier: ΔY/ΔT = -MPC/(1-MPC). Balanced budget multiplier = 1 (since ΔG = ΔT implies ΔY = ΔG). IS-LM extension: IS curve (goods market): Y = C(Y-T) + I(r) + G. LM curve (money market): M/P = L(Y, r). Equilibrium where both clear. Fiscal policy shifts IS. Monetary policy shifts LM. In liquidity trap, LM horizontal at zero bound - monetary policy ineffective, fiscal policy fully effective.

mathematical_formulation.consumption_function: C = C₀ + MPC × (Y - T) where C₀ is autonomous consumption, MPC ∈ (0,1)
mathematical_formulation.equilibrium_income: Y = [1/(1-MPC)] × [C₀ - MPC×T + I + G] = k × [A] where k = 1/(1-MPC) is multiplier, A is autonomous spending
mathematical_formulation.is_curve: Y = C(Y-T, r) + I(r) + G - goods market equilibrium, downward-sloping in (Y,r) space
mathematical_formulation.lm_curve: M/P = L(Y, r) - money market equilibrium, upward-sloping in (Y,r) space
mathematical_formulation.liquidity_preference: L(Y, r) = kY - hr where k = income elasticity, h = interest elasticity of money demand

fiscal_policy_tools.government_spending: Direct increase in AD - multiplier effect. Most effective in recession (slack resources, low interest rates)
fiscal_policy_tools.taxation: Tax cuts increase disposable income, boost consumption. Smaller multiplier than spending (some saved)
fiscal_policy_tools.automatic_stabilizers: Progressive taxes, unemployment insurance automatically smooth cycles without legislation

monetary_policy_tools.interest_rate_targeting: Lower rates encourage investment, higher rates cool overheating economy
monetary_policy_tools.liquidity_trap: At zero lower bound, conventional monetary policy exhausted - fiscal policy needed
monetary_policy_tools.quantitative_easing: Central bank asset purchases when rates at zero - unconventional monetary policy

policy_lags.decision_lag: Time to agree on and pass legislation (political process)
policy_lags.implementation_lag: Time to spend money effectively (project planning)
policy_lags.impact_lag: Time for spending to affect economy (multiplier works slowly)

keynesian_schools.original_keynesian: Keynes 1936 - emphasis on uncertainty, animal spirits, liquidity preference
keynesian_schools.neoclassical_synthesis: Hicks, Samuelson 1950s-60s - IS-LM formalization, Keynesian short run + classical long run
keynesian_schools.post_keynesian: Minsky, Robinson - financial instability, endogenous money, rejecting classical synthesis
keynesian_schools.new_keynesian: Mankiw, Stiglitz 1980s+ - microfoundations for sticky prices, DSGE models, mainstream today

provenance.verification_notes: Content verified against Keynes's original General Theory, standard textbooks, and empirical literature on fiscal multipliers. Mathematical formulations derived from textbook presentations. Historical examples cross-referenced with BEA, BLS, NBER data.

verified_claims.derivation: Y = C₀ + MPC(Y-T) + I + G. Differentiate w.r.t. G: dY/dG = MPC·dY/dG + 1. Solve: dY/dG(1-MPC) = 1, so dY/dG = 1/(1-MPC) ✓
Y = C₀ + MPC(Y-T) + I + G. Differentiate w.r.t. T: dY/dT = MPC·dY/dT - MPC. Solve: dY/dT(1-MPC) = -MPC, so dY/dT = -MPC/(1-MPC) ✓
If ΔG = ΔT: Total effect = ΔG/(1-MPC) + ΔT×(-MPC/(1-MPC)) = ΔG[1/(1-MPC) - MPC/(1-MPC)] = ΔG[(1-MPC)/(1-MPC)] = ΔG ✓

verified_claims.claim: In liquidity trap (r at zero bound), fiscal policy is fully effective
verified_claims.derivation: When LM is horizontal (liquidity trap), fiscal expansion (IS shift right) increases Y without raising r, so no crowding out occurs. Full multiplier effect realized ✓
